displayed_text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: so I want to share it with you guys. Other than that, this is not like chemo. This is not like anything else. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: So the tiredness is the top three that really will be wiping you out. Sometimes it makes you feel so wiped out… Patient: Wait a minute, W__ I got a compliment for you Healthcare Professional: Uh, huh? Patient: Doctor- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -hold on for one second. Doctor: Oh, okay. Healthcare Professional: Uh,huh. Patient: So you said, you said well I know you got the six hundred Motrin, you got eight hundred Motrin, but then we had the morphine and all that other stuff.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Uh, the – we always ask about pain, you know. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, because pain does mean -- pain means we gotta do something now. Family Member: I get it. Doctor: Most people don’t have pain. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But people in the old days, maybe your father, you think about it, you know, um, that was pain that you remember. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Uh. But because of our better therapies, men have less pain. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: He’s got a lot of disease in his bone that there may be that they can’t sense pain. Family Member: Okay. Alright. Yeah. Alright.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Hum? Patient: Cancer’s like, uh, cancer is like a mucous. Doctor: Cancer is like a mucous? Patient: Huh. Doctor: Nah Family Member: I was always taught it’s an overgrowth of whatever. Doctor: Yeah. The cancer cells- Family Member: The cells just keep reproducing, reproducing, reproducing. Doctor: That’s it. It doesn’t know when to stop growing, which is the problem. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s, you know, affected your bones. It’s affected some of the lymph nodes. So is it going like crazy gangbusters? No. Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s actually a group that would get you back to California. There’s a group at UCLA (laughs) Patient: And how does, what’s the effect of that when you get treated? I mean what is, what’s different about that? Would that, would that go after the growth in the lymph nodes? Doctor: Yes. So PSMA is a thing that’s on the surface of crossing cancer cells. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it’s an enzyme, which means uh we’re not really sure what it does but we are, we’re able to block its function with a with a small drug. Uh and what people actually here when we started doing it, uh people thought well that would be cool to take an image of the cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know-

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If patients are a Gleason score of eight or more, high risk of progression. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If it’s a Gleason score of seven I would consider that and intermediate risk and a Gleason score of seven Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Two ways of having a Gleason score of seven.
